terms.definition: A lattice in wavevector (k) space constructed from the Fourier transform of the real-space lattice. Each point represents a plane wave with the periodicity of the crystal.
The Wigner-Seitz cell of the reciprocal lattice. The first BZ contains all unique wavevectors, as any k outside it is equivalent to a k inside it plus a reciprocal lattice vector.
The region of space closer to one lattice point than any other. Constructed by drawing perpendicular bisectors to all lattice vectors from a chosen origin.
A plane in k-space that satisfies the Bragg diffraction condition 2k·G = |G|². It forms the boundary of a Brillouin zone.
A point in the Brillouin zone invariant under a subset of the crystal's symmetry operations. Band energies often have extrema at these points.
The center of the Brillouin zone at k = 0. All crystal symmetry operations leave Γ invariant.
The relationship between electron energy E and wavevector k within the Brillouin zone. Determines electronic properties of solids.
A quantum of lattice vibration. Phonon dispersion relations ω(k) are defined within the Brillouin zone.
The surface in k-space separating occupied from unoccupied electron states at absolute zero. Its shape within the BZ determines metallic properties.
A set of integers (hkl) that specify a reciprocal lattice vector G = hb₁ + kb₂ + lb₃ and the family of crystal planes perpendicular to it.
The process of mapping k-points from higher Brillouin zones back into the first zone by subtracting appropriate reciprocal lattice vectors.
States that electron wavefunctions in a periodic potential have the form ψ_k(r) = e^(ik·r) u_k(r), where u_k has the periodicity of the lattice.
